newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - APRIL 10.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - APRIL 10.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press. Today's press digest is late due to a work stoppage by newspaper distributors this morning.

--The government will place the emphasis on changes to the job market during talks with unionists and employers to start soon, according to Prime Minister Costas Simitis. The government will aim for the greatest possible consensus on forging a new regime in the job market while putting the discussion on social insurance on the back burner. Simitis was speaking at the Economist Roundtable with the Greek government last night.
--Tomorrow's meeting between bank employee representatives and the Association of Greek Banks will determine the fate of the new collective wage agreement for banks.
--The National Mortgage Bank will proceed with a new rescheduling of debts owed by tourist enterprises, totalling 66 billion drachmas.

--Simitis yesterday extended an invitation to the business world to invest and contribute to the development of competitiveness and, subsequently, to the Greek economy. 1997 will be a milestone for the country's entry to Economic and Monetary Union, the prime minister said, adding that workers and employers must contribute to achieve convergence.

--The finding of extra resources for pension funds is a priority, Simitis said during his meeting at the labour ministry yesterday. The government will target those not paying their share of contributions to the funds.

--Changes to the job market under consideration have become a sore point within the government and ruling party PASOK. The official beginning to social dialogue begins today with the meeting of the joint government-party committee on procedural issues on the dialogue.
--Greece's drachma will join the euro zone by the year 2001, Bank of Greece Governor Lucas Papademos affirmed at the Economist conference yesterday.

--The merger of National Insurance, ETEBA Insurance and Astera will see 120 billion drachmas in policies this year. National last year posted profits of 1.5 billion drachmas and 74 billion drachmas in policies.
--Today's meeting of the government's economic team chaired by Prime Minister Simitis will focus on disappointing rates of revenues in the first quarter.
